description: From Medieval Latin carula, probably from Latin corolla (“little crown”) in the sense of “ring”; or from Middle English caroll, from Medieval Latin carola, from Late Latin carola (“round dance; round object”), from Latin choraula, variant of choraulēs (“flute player”) (further etymology at carol).

entries.meaning: (architecture) A small closet or enclosure built against a window on the inner side, to sit in for study.
Hence, a partially partitioned space for studying or reading, often in a library.
examples: He was busy writing his report in a small library carrel.
